title: 'Premature' closure of Qld coal plant 'dire': Taylor
text:
Mr Taylor has criticised the state-based targets as encouraging a rapid influx of solar and wind projects while squeezing out more reliable coal- and gas-fired power stations.

"State governments have a responsibility to families and businesses to keep the lights on," said Mr Taylor, who is due give a keynote address at The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit on Wednesday.

"Premier Palaszczuk only needs to look at the mess in Victoria created by the premature closure of Hazelwood to see the risks of the path they are embarking on."

But Queensland Energy Minister Anthony Lynham said the ultimate decision about when to close the state's coal-fired power stations would be up to the state government.

He said the information given to the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) - which brought forward the closure date for the 700 megawatt Callide B power station in Central Queensland from 2038-39 to 2028 - was due to an update of technical specifications of the power plant which was commissioned in 1988.

"It does not reflect government decisions or policy. As I said, the government and the people of Queensland decide when they close. No-one else," Dr Lynham said.

"Unlike in southern states - where power stations are privately-owned - the government will decide when power stations are retired.

"And in the future when we do, as the renewable energy transition continues, the local communities and the workers will be looked after under our transition policies."

CFMEU mining and energy division Queensland president Steve Smyth said the closure of Callide B would have a big impact in Central Queensland, with no obvious reliable replacement for coal-fired power.

"There will be job losses and it will have a massive effect on the local community," he said.

"Again these decisions being suggested and still no evidence of how other power generation will ensure cheap and reliable power. I don't believe a lot of these so called experts really understand the effect of wanting to shut down the coal industry."

Dr Lynham - who has admitted the state's coal-fired power stations would be squeezed out of the grid by renewable energy projects, but not before 2030 - said Queensland's coal fleet was the youngest in the nation and the stations were maintained to ensure their reliability.

Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's government is particularly sensitive to criticism about the coal sector after it was accused of doing a "go slow" on approvals for Adani's $2 billion Carmichael mine, which contributed to Labor's poor showing in Queensland in the federal election.

AEMO's latest database of generating unit closures shows the state-owned 1680 megawatt Gladstone power station will stay open for five more years than expected and was now scheduled to close in 2035.

Another state-owned coal-fired power station in Queensland, the 1400 megawatt Tarong facility, will close in 2036-37 as planned, while the newer 1445 megawatt Stanwell plant, which was commissioned in 1993, will not close until 2044-45.

Clean energy advocates welcomed the news about the proposed earlier closure of Callide B, saying it made sense in the move to a low-emissions economy.

Advertisement

"Significant advance notice of the closure of Callide B power station allows ample time for new investment in renewable energy and energy storage to ensure the Queensland energy system remains reliable and energy prices affordable," Clean Energy Council chief executive Kane Thornton said.

"This will also make further progress on Queensland's 50 per cent renewable energy target."

The federal and NSW governments in August launched a taskforce to examine the closure of the Liddell power plant and ensure there was not a repeat of the Hazelwood closure.

Other key coal-fired power plant closures in the grid include Sunset Power's Vales Point in 2028, EnergyAustralia's Yallourn plant in Victoria in 2032 and AGL Energy's Bayswater in 2035.
description: The federal energy minister warned Queensland is risking a repeat of the "mess" in Victoria created with the early closure of the Hazelwood power station.
